title: Following the 2021 German Bundestag elections, which parties will be part of the new government?
possible_answers: The CDU but not the Green Party
The Green Party but not the CDU
Both the CDU and the Green Party
Neither the CDU nor the Green Party
No government will be formed before 31 December 2021
correct_answer: The Green Party but not the CDU
preds:
Added after elections started.
Too close between tattoo to sleep to exclude either grand coalition possible negotiations not completed until end of year not likely

Merkel out campaigning for CDU is bringing them closer to catching SPD.   So there's a chance of a CDU/SPD alliance as it has been through this last government.  Was thinking that the last bucket 'no govt' buxket had too high a crowd forecast, but it took over four months for the current coalition to be formed in 2018 so will raise my % there accordingly.  
  https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-58689239
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-42973419

Assuming the results turn out roughly according to the polls,  I'm expecting long and complicated coalition negotiations and I'm quite certain the Greens will be in the new government, regardless how long it will take to form one. There is no way around the Greens unless the CDU/CSU distort themselves beyond recognition to be the minor partner in a coaltion with the SPD, so that gets a generous 4%. I think the Greens are going to be the Center of any negotiations and can get quite a lot of their demands, when they play Conserservatives and SPD against each other, especially when Greens and FDP quickly find a common ground. So the big unknowns at moment are: 1. What is the FDP doing? Because FDP and Union will get along pretty quickly and I asume also Union and Greens would (surprisingly quickly to most people)  agree on most issues. That was already appearent four years ago, when the FDP all of a sudden withdraw from coaliton talks. I think in the end it will come down either Jamaica (Union-Green-FDP) or Red-Green-Red. Traffic light seems to me not likely the moment (although quite a lot of people would like to see that), especially when Greens and FDP not coming to a common ground at one point. If that results in a government, I'm not expecting that it will last for four years. I expect long and complicated talks between the parties but also within the parties, especially within the CDU  (sorting out the post merkel future within the party), the FDP (party has been a Christian Lindner one man show the last four years), the Left (sticking to doctine and fundamentally to opposition or taking a more practical approach and seeking government responsibility).

Coalitions considered most probable:
> SPD, FDP and Greens: High probability of winning > 50% (0.7), but low probability to form coalition (0.15)
> SPD, Left and Greens: Low probability of winning > 50% (0.4), but high probability to form a coalition (0.7)
SPD felt to have won the TV debate.  Getting close to the Greens.   https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/sep/19/centre-left-german-election-candidate-eager-to-form-government-with-greens
Best guess. Vote early. Vote often.

I assume "no gov. will be formed ..." covers the (very plausible) case of negotiations still going on by 31.12. but no new election is called. As many three party coalition options will be possible negotiations are very likely to be prolonged. I say 60% chance of not being finished by 31.12.
Case "Neither" would mean a coalition of SPD, Linke, FDP, AfD which is politically well nigh impossible.
Case "Greens but not CDU/CSU" would mean coalition of SPD, Greens, FDP or SPD, Greens, Linke. Both would options would be possible if current polls would not change but both options would be politically difficult. I give them together 40% x (15%+10%)=10%.
Case "CDU/CSU but not Greens" would mean coalition of CDU/CSU, SPD, FDP or CDU/CSU, SPD. I give them 40% x (20% + 7,5%)=11%
Updating given the recent survey results: https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/insa.htm

Guten Morgen @CJH, the Corona crisis plays no role at all in the german election. Climate, environment and justice are the issues. From a purely substantive point of view, a coalition of SPD-Greens-Left would fit together; at the moment, Germans most want a traffic light coalition of SPD-Greens-FDP. 
The FDP, however, would prefer a coalition with the CDU and the Greens. Recently, a coalition of SPD and CDU has also become possible again. The parties have now already announced exploratory talks after the elections for various combinations. I think these talks will take longer than before, I estimate up to four weeks. When it comes to coalition talks, for example, between the SPD, the Greens and the FDP, it could take a very long time because the Greens and the FDP sometimes have completely contradictory content. These talks could fail after 4-8 weeks. Then there are new specialization talks and coalition negotiations again - and all the sudden there is Christmas. Current example: Netherlands. There, the formation of a government has been ongoing for six months.

Under current polling, Jamaica now not enough to win majority.  Only slight, and polls could obviously be wrong/change, but looking a less likely and less attractive option. So going down CDU + Green https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/aug/20/german-election-poll-tracker-who-will-be-the-next-chancellor

I continue my prediction that the Greens will be part of the next government by over 80%. I lowered my estimate of having the CDU in the government but not the Greens, because Armin Laschet announced, that the Conservatives would not join a government as a minor partner. However there might be still a slight chance, that the Conservatives will still join as a minor, because being in the opposition is also not a popular option for many of them. I increase the chance of having no government at the end of 2021. At the moment there seems five (more of less) viable constellations of forming a government, but all of them require three parties, which would make negotiations, with plenty of bitter pills to swallow plus the approvals by all the involved party bases much more complicated and time consuming. And in case of failure this all starts all over again.

Another poll that sees the SPD far ahead.
https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/emnid.htm At the moment five coalitions would be possible, 4 of them SPD led. 
SPD, CDU and Greens (politically very unlikely) 
SPD, Union and FDP (politically very unlikely)
SPD, Greens and FDP 
SPD, Greens and Left
CDU, Greens and FDP The trend suggests that the CDU will be removed from power in Berlin.
Many election researchers in Germany believe that the parties' core clientele is shrinking and that voters are therefore giving their votes more often to other parties. The CDU can only hope to get the votes of its core clientele. Only then do they have a chance of remaining in power.

In the last poll, the SPD is 5% ahead of the CDU:
https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/insa.htm
Nevertheless, given the voter potential, it is likely that the CDU will catch up again by election day at the latest. It is very likely that it will be very close between the CDU and SPD and that there will be many coalition variants. Therefore, the probability has become high that there will be more than one coalition negotiation as in 2017. If the CDU becomes the strongest force, it will start the talks, but they may fail if the Greens drop out and continue negotiating with SPD and Left or FDP. 
So there is a realistic chance that no new federal government will be sworn in this year. In the last federal election on September 24, 2017, the first coalition negotiations failed and after a total of 5 months and 5 days, the new government was sworn in.

The trend is confirmed: SPD and CDU are roughly on a par:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_German_federal_election On ZDF public television, the Greens are also back in the race:
https://www.zdf.de/nachrichten/politik/politbarometer-bundestagswahl-union-spd-gleichauf-100.html The head of the FDP Christian Lindner is seen as a kingmaker, because politically realistic are the coalitions CDU/Greens/FDP and SPD/Greens/FDP. He would prefer to govern with the CDU. At present, an SPD/Greens/Left alliance also seems possible, which the SPD would rather enter than a coalition of CDU, SPD and FDP, and which the FDP would like to avoid at all costs, and would therefore also enter a traffic light coalition with SPD and Greens.

Merkel has just openly endorsed Laschet, but she has neither the coattails nor the physical strength that the the tired-looking CDU boss can run on. The SPD's Scholz while not a fresh face would be a far better coalition partner with Greens, and character and photogenics less apt to become a "patzer" than Laschet, who is hardly a Michael Kohl. The following quote from Berliner Tagesspiegel offers some insight... "Die SPD mit Kanzlerkandidat Olaf Scholz holt im Rennen um die Wählergunst einer Umfrage zufolge auf. In einer am Mittwoch veröffentlichten Forsa-Erhebung für die Bundestagwahl am 26. September liegt die Union mit ihrem Kandidaten Armin Laschet (CDU) nur noch zwei Prozentpunkte vor der SPD. ...Demnach kommt im RTL/ntv-Trendbarometer die CDU/CSU bei der Sonntagsfrage („Wen würden Sie wählen, wenn am kommenden Sonntag Bundestagswahl wäre?“) unverändert auf 23 Prozent, die SPD liegt bei 21 Prozent (plus zwei)."   https://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/olaf-scholz-holt-in-umfrage-weiter-auf-spd-liegt-nur-noch-zwei-punkte-hinter-der-union/27527352.html

With a Olaf Scholz in a rise, and most popular leader (SPD) i can assume that he can be Merkel's successor, SPD should be in the coalition.
Just a quick slight update, but it seems like the CDU and Greens are heading to be a part of another coalition government, probably with the CDU at the helm.

- CDU alone: <5%
- CDU+FPD (+AfD): <5%
- CDU+SPD: 15%
- CDU+Grünen (+FDP): 50% (-5%)
- SPD+Grünen + (FDP/Die Linke): 25% (+5%) Tweaking after looking more at current polling numbers, and this is now a fairly big deviation from the crowd. A Grünen+SPD (+FPD) coalition might be possible.  In addition, numbers are looking close, and there is the additional complication that Scholz would be more popular as a chancellor than Laschet, so negotiations might really drag on. Might change my mind later.

My thinking becomes clearer if I think in terms of coalitions:
- CDU alone: <5%
- CDU+FPD (+AfD): <5%
- CDU+SPD: 15%
- CDU+Grünen (+FDP): 55%
- SPD+Grünen + (FDP/Die Linke): 20% I expect these probabilities to become sharper (i.e., for CDU+Grünen to go to 100%) as I think more about this.

The conventional wisdom in the water supply is that the CDU+Die Grünen are going to form a coalition. Reasons to think that this might not be the case:
- While the CDU enjoys broad support, Scholz (the SPD's candidate) is way more popular than Laschet (the CDU's candidate)
- It's not clear to me that an SPD+Grünen coalition is that implausible.
- The CDU might enjoy fewer support now that Merkel (perceived as a benevolent, highly intelligent figure, has a physics background), is replaced by Laschet. For instance, I could conceive voting for Merkel on account of the competency and stability, but Laschet is much less palatable. 
- Polling error may make assumptions obsolete. 
- I thought that a first pass the post system would favor the CDU, but reading the Wikipedia page (https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Mixed-member_proportional_representation), this is not the case (!): Bundestag members represent their constituencies in a first pass-the post way, but new members are added to ensure proportionality (smart!) Overall, I get the impression that this is a "is conventional opinion correct" question, and I'm just not sure. *** Base rates are currently confusing, because the FPD, a "classical liberal" party which often acted as kingmaker, and the SPD, the leftist party, have both massively decreased in power in recent years, and die Grünen have characteristics of both.

The candidates of both CDU and Greens doing not so well, after the floods in the West of Germany, the Taliban takeover in Afghanistan and most of all both of them are perceived of lacking integrity for different reasons. So the SPD and their candidate are doing relatively well, which gives them a not unrealistic chance of actually forming a coalition. At the moment it looks like there will be several viable options of forming a government unlike after the last election, when nobody was really happy with the result. For me it comes down to the question: How likely is it, that the Greens will be part of the next government. I think the probability of the Greens joining the government is at least 80%. Why? Because they are hungry for power after 16 years of opposition. The CDU sees itself as the "naturaly rightful" ruling party. Additionally  the CDU moved under Angela Merkel considerably away from many classic conservative positions. So not unreasonable to assume them both in the next government and actually getting along quite well with each other. This why I see CDU and Greens over 50% in the next government, but also for the Greens having realistically also options cooperating with other parties.

SPD is on the rise according to the latest surveys: https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/. I do not expect that they will win the race, but it is possible. Then the CDU would probably not be part of the new Government. The Green Party should be: of cause if they win (not very probable), but they are also the first coalition partner for both the CDU and the SPD.

The momentum is in favor of the SPD with its candidate for chancellor, Scholz, which is only 1% behind the CDU in this latest poll. 
https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/emnid.htm Laschet (CDU) seems to share the same fate as Martin Schulz (SPD) four years ago, who started well as a candidate for chancellor, then crashed and is now irrelevant in politics. Scholz can be said to have a certain international stature; Laschet and Baerbock currently do not. 
The SPD and the Greens, as center-left parties, will very likely get slightly more than 40% of the vote, the CDU and the FDP, as center-right parties, less so, currently 35%-40%. If the SPD becomes the second-strongest force, which is what it looks like at the moment, I see a 50 percent chance of a traffic light coalition (SPD-Green-FDP).

To factors are quite clear to me: (1) No party will launch a coalition with the AfD, so they are out. (2) CDU and SPD will try to avoid a coalition at all costs. Their profile would get lost and they would loose more voters if they would continue their coalition. According to the current poll numbers (https://www.bundestagswahl-2021.de/umfragen/) both the CDU and the Green Party are definitely part of the new coalition. Green, red and yellow would be possible, but not very likely, since CDU is stronger and the FDP (yellow) has a greater affiliation with the CDU (black). The Green Party could go with both.

As of today,  if we assume SPD and CDU are not going to form another coalition again (which i doubt because they would still need FDP/Greens to do it), Jamaica and Traffic light coalition are the only options. Jamaica is plenty attractive for FDP and CDU but not necessarily for the greens.  Traffic light coalition might be highly attractive to Greens (chancelorship), SPD (stay in power/ maybe chancelorship) but not the FDP.  Base case is Jamaica, but FDP vs Greens is a tension in both cases. This leaves me to consider re-elections more likely.

Fairly big probability changes. It feels to me very unlikely that the two biggest parties are not Green and CDU and that they could not have a strong majority. Probably above 85% even this far out. So the question becomes - would the CDU/CSU not enter a coalition with the greens or vice versa. Could the CDU/CSU mathematically have a coalition that works without the Greens. Possibly, they have a lot of potential partners and it feels probably around a third, maybe a bit less, probability (they currently total just under 45% of polling averages) they the left, AfD and greens get to over 50%. But would they? Feels very unlikely. The Greens would have done hugely well, Germany is used to coalitions and it feels relatively easily to come up with a common vision with a lot of environmental policy. Optics of excluding them feels awful both for CDU/CSU and for the potentially multiple coalition partners they would need. Could the Greens have a coalition that works mathematically without the CDU/CSU. Here - probably similar or slightly higher probability. Would think the only partner they would fully rule out would be AfD, so maths is slightly easier. But it is not obvious why they would do it in most cases. Green / SPD would seem the most obvious from their perspective, but a) mathematically that probably will not work (combined polling currently around 40% so maybe c 15% they would get to the right number?) and b) why not go with a broader coalition and have an overwhelming majority.  They can always try something else later. FDP or multi party seems less stable. So why do them if you have a willing coalition partner in CDU/CSU? So let’s say:
Just Greens - 15% works with SDP but only 40% chance they do it. Plus a percent or two for something more out of left field. 8%
Just CDU/CSU - maybe 67% it is broadly possible but only 5% they take it up/ can deliver. 3%
Putting 3% for no government (feels like the only way that happens is a massive CDU/CSU and green falling out. And 1% for neither (probably high.
Leaves 85% for both. Making a lot of assumptions about optics of different coalitions and outcomes in a country I do not know that well, so would love a view from any Germans or German politics experts.

CDU/CSU going down and Green's going up in opinion polls, but FDP going up and SDP going down. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_German_federal_election#Opinion_polls So basically you have the Greens doing better, but there most obvious alternative coalition partner doing worse, and the CDU/CSU doing worse, but their most obvious alternative coalition partner doing better. Overall, feels like it increase the probability it is Green CSU/CDU, both because mathematically it seems unlikely that other coalitions will work, and also because it seems hard for CSU/CDU to try and form a coalitions without them. Just been being a bit "hacky" and moved probability from the CDU/CSU only to both

Opinion polls say momentarily CDU has about 25% +-, Green Party about 20++ %, SPD about 15%++, Linke about 10% -+, FDP about 5%++, AFD about 10%.  Two blocks may form the new Government: CDU(max) + Green or Green(max) + CDU xor Green(max) + SPD + Linke. (max) party lead the new government and determine the chancellor. I assume that CDU + Green + FDP has also a certain probability, even Green Party and FDP cooperate only on very few topics in the past. Green + SPD + Linke + FDP Government will happen only and only if FDP is keen to govern independently of its party program. CDU + FDP has lower probability due to momentarily opinion poll shares of both parties.  The shares of votes for Parties might be therefore like this on next election for next Bundestag from my point of view: No Leadership by CDU, no great coalition by CDU and SPD, no majority by red/red/green, SPD/LINKE/Green, no majority by CDU and Green and no chancellor Laschet possible. Yes majority by Green, then Leadership to build Government and establish the proposal of chancellor possible, yes CDU > SPD and/or Green > CDU, but Green + CDU < 49,9 % on Bundestag, yes FDP > Linke and/or Green+FDP+SPD < 49,9%, therefore CDU + FDP << 49,9% and CDU+FDP > Green. Conclusion: Green lead Government and establish the proposal for Chancellor but will be controlled by majority of government that are CDU + FDP. Therefore I expect a coalition of Green+CDU+FDP by 52% or so.  Baseline facts from my perspective: The voters of CDU are 60 or older. About 25 millions adults or so are retired and are extremely conservative. 13 millions adults or so have an age between 55 and 65. That means half of population are retired or are going on retirement soon. 10 million children going to schools or universities or doing an apprenticeship. About 10 Millionen or so are migrants and do not have citizenship of Germany and can not elect. The rest do not going to election. Gerontology part of society will determine the election. The whole society has to pay for retired people about 330 Billion Euro per year. The normal budget of Germany is about 340 billions Euro. The transfer duties of young population to retired people are extreme and will be more extremer in this decade due to demographics. Therefore the Germany society is a transfer society.: retired people, young people, etc.. The Germans hate Change, hate Technology, hate Capitalism, hate Industry, hate China, hate USA, hate EU, hate Foreigners, hate military people, ... The CDU + SPD governments after about 15 years have a legacy: Insufficient administration, insufficient infrastructure, insufficient digitalization, ... Revolution is being needed. The outcome of election might be that a new government are elected that ensures going ahead with same, or the outcome is shocking > Communism > Green + Linke + SPD. They dream: The cow is being fed in the heaven and is creating golden ducats on the flat earth. All people love each other. Therefore military service is nonsense. Intelligence services should be removed. Any form of capitalism must be disestablished. Corona management in the next months may have an effect on voters to held CDU and SPD accountable.

I changed a bit the probabilities of my last forecast. I lowered the probability of having no government formed until end of the year. I do that because Germans don't like uncertainty and adding to that, long negotiations of a new coalition only benefit the AfD, so rather continuing such an unease, someone is going to swallow some bitter pills. My take for the moment is Greens and the Union, if they get enough seats together. The Greens because they are eager to get into power, and in their mindset, they have been way to long in the opposition. The Union on the other hand probably going to have some heated dicussions about joining in or leading the opposition, similar to the SPD four years ago. But to be a junior in government is a rather foreign thought to them, which they first have to get used to. 
When numbers are so, that a government can't formed without the Union, they are grudgingly joining, cause avoiding uncertainty, but not without some turmoil within the party. I increased the probability that Union will be in the government but not the Greens and decreasing government with the Greens but now Union. I do that, cause there is, in my estimate, the hype the Greens got from nominating their chanceller candidate is going to dampen a bit, while the Union after the more chaotic nomination is closing their ranks.
The greens will get the majority of votes, the CDU being the junior partner. Candidates of the greens appeal much mote to the majority of younger voters- they will decide the election.

Possible coalition partners for Union and Greens:
Union: FDP, SPD, and the Greens
Union with FDP and SPD would probably fall short of a majority, also SPD could be reluctant to join such a coalition increasing the odds of the greens joining Union with either SPD or FDP. 
Greens: SPD, Linke, Union, FDP
Greens, SPD and Linke would probably fall short of a majority and FDP would probably not join such a coalition again increasing the odds of a Green-Union government.  Given current polls I assume a Union-Green coalition possibly with FDP or SPD. If this option fails I think Union has more change with PDP and SPD than the Greens have with SPD, Linke, and FDP. A no Union, no Green seems very unlikely given the current polls. It would require all other parties to work together, unlikely since the FDP would probably shun Die Linke, and Die Linke and SPD would shun AfD. Still, polls could change before september so I give it a 1%.  The longest formation in post war Germany took 86 days so no government at the start of 2022 looks unlikely. However, current polling suggest a high probability of a 3 party coalition increasing formation time.

P( "WIN>50%" ) : Probability that the parties concerned win more than 50 %
  of the votes P( "UNITE" ) : Probability that the parties concerned choose this coalition
  option (among other possible options) Result = P( "WIN>50%" ) * P( "UNITE" ) ==================================================
Possible Coalitions
================================================== < Coalition | P( "WIN>50%" ) | P( "UNITE" ) | Result | Bucket > CDU + FDP | 0.1 | 0.95 | 0.095 | CDU only CDU + SPD | 0.2 | 0.25 | 0.05 | CDU only SPD + Green Party | 0.2 | 0.8 | 0.16 | Greens only CDU + AFD | 0.1 | 0.1 | 0.01 | CDU only CDU + Green Party | 0.6 | 0.2 | 0.12 | CDU and Greens CDU + FDP + AFD | 0.45 | 0.02 | 0.009 | CDU only CDU + SPD + Green Party | 0.75 | 0.05 | 0.0375 | CDU and Greens CDU + FDP + Green Party | 0.65 | 0.1 | 0.065 | CDU and Greens CDU + SPD + FDP | 0.5 | 0.05 | 0.025 | CDU only SPD + FDP + Green Party | 0.5 | 0.1 | 0.05 | Greens only SPD + Left Party + Green Party | 0.5 | 0.25 | 0.125 | Greens only Checksum: 0.7465 -> 0.2535 left for "no government" option ==================================================
Summary
================================================== CDU only: 0.19 ~ 19 %
Greens only: 33.5 ~ 34 %

Mainly because, a government with only one of them, would be quite unstable (if at all possible), because of just a tiny majority in a multiparty coalition covering a relatively wide political spectrum. The question is: Do they have a majority together? If yes, they will quickly get an agreement and form the new government. They had already talks after the last election together with the FDP. This talks actually went, to the surprise of a lot of observers, well between Greens and CDU/CSU, but failed in end because the FDP pulled suddenly out. So Greens and CDU would go along quite well with each other. The other possiblity is they are going to need a third partner and this might be tricky to get an agreement there until end of 2021. There are only limited indications that the CDU faces the prospects of diminished electoral victories.  The Green Party could be squeezed out of government if the CDU decides to form another grand coalition with the SPD with a combined majority or find another partner(s).  The prospects of the SPD in generally appears to be stagnant with the slight possibility of picking up a couple of seats, but equally possible of losing seats.  The differences between the CDU and SPD, while at times can be stark, in general under Merkel has been closer ideologically,  The SPD simply does not have enough coalition options to form a government, barring a major shake up in the election.  It is highly likely that the CDU and SPD will form another government with other partners, but the SPD may attempt to press for the formation of their own government or, more likely, press for concession from the CDU before entering into a grand coalition that may push the formation of a government into 2022.

Overview
================================================== First I try to map the German political landscape to the US: Democrats from left (like Bernie Sanders) to center-left (like Joe Biden)
would correspond approximately to these parties: Left Party, Green Party, SPD, approx. half of the CDU/CSU Republicans from center-right (have no example here) to right (like Donald Trump)
would correspond approximately to: the other half of the CDU/CSU, FDP, AFD Current Trends
================================================== Recent Polls:
================================================== -> https://www.bundestagswahl-2021.de/umfragen/
  The first figure shows the recent trend  for the election (average value
  of four different polls) -> https://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/
  More polls Coalition Calculations:
==================================================  -> https://www.bundestagswahl-2021.de/koalitionen/
  Shows possible coalitions and what coaltitions where formed in the past Forecast Decomposition
================================================== I try to assign some probabilities to the most possible outcomes of the
election. To reduce the number of possibilities I assume that all parties
have these preferences regarding the formation of a government coalition: Reign alone > coalition of two > coalition of three >
  > no government is formed > form a minority government So everybody would prefer to reign alone the most and being in a minority
government the least. Exotic Futures
================================================== Since 1961 no party could win an absolute majority in Germany and the recent
polls say that it will stay so. Consequently I assign zero probability to
these possibilities. There were 4 minority governments in Germany at the federal level, but all were
the result of a coalition crisis and only an interim solution
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minority_government#Germany). Furthermore I would
regard the formation of a minority government in times of COVID in Germany very
unlikely. So zero probability for these outcomes too. Possible coalitions that currently have voter support much lower than 50% or
would simply explode if somebody would try to establish them are also considered
impossible (zero prob.). Two Party Coalitions
================================================== In order to be formed (1) both parties together must get more than 50% of the votes
and (2) both must be willing to form a coalition. So the probability for a successful
government formation is:   P( "WIN>50%" ) * P( "UNITE" ) NOTE: When I try to estimate P( "UNITE" ), I assume that the concerned parties have
the majority needed. But this doesn't mean that this is the only majority availible.
If, for example, the CDU has a majority together with the SPD, it is pretty likely
that the CDU could also choose another coalition partner. Furthermore time is
playing a role here. Some coalition options never existed before on the federal level
and would bring together very diverse political views. So in these cases it could take
forever to form a coalition and the timeframe for the forecast would simply end. The two party options worth considering are: CDU + FDP "Black and Yellow Coalition"
================================================== Happened often in the past, but low probability now:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.2 CDU and FDP are politically close and would form a coalition:   P( "UNITE" ) = 0.95 CDU + SPD "Grand Coalition"
================================================== Happened often in the (recent) times, but both the CDU and the SPD are in
a downward trend:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.3 This ist the coalition that reigns Germany now, but both sides seem not to be eager to
continue this arrangement due to political differences:    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.25 SPD + FDP
================================================== Existed seldom in the past and currently very unlikely to win a majority:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0 SPD + Green Party
================================================== Green Party in upward trend but weaker than the CDU, SPD in downward trend:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.2 Were in power from 1998 to 2005, so could be revived again:    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.8 CDU + AFD
================================================== AFD is weaker than the SPD, so:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.2 The AFD is a pariah in the german political landscape and no other party is
willing to cooperate with the AFD. But the CDU is politically close to the
AFD (especially considering the voter base) and cooperation might eventually
occur. Nevertheless the CDU would probably prefer FDP, SPD or the Green Party,
if possible.    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.1 CDU + Green Party
================================================== The only two party coalition that would have a (light) majority 
according to recent polls:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.45 The Green Party and the CDU on the federal level never formed a
coalition before, and negotiating one could be difficult due to
strong political differences of the voter bases.    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.15 Three Party Coalitions
================================================== Bringing three of the german parties together can be considered more difficult.
So P( "UNITE" ) should be much lower in general in the three party case. CDU + FDP + AFD
================================================== Approximately same number of supporters like CDU + Green Party:   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.4 As discussed above coalitions with AFD are dangerous and in this case
two parties have to succumb to the temptation. On the other hand the
political differences between these three parties are surmountable.    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.02 CDU + SPD + Green Party
================================================== These are the three largest parties in Germany, so it is really possible
that they can win more than 50% of the votes.   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.65 It is less likely that CDU + SPD + Green Party have a majority but
CDU + Green Party not. Furthermore both SPD and the Green Party must
tolerate the politically rather distant CDU and vice versa. Such a
coalition has never existed on the federal level.    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.05 CDU + FDP + Green Party "Jamaica Coalition"
==================================================   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.55 Such a coalition was almost formed in 2017 on the federal level.
FDP opted out and suffered losses. So they might decide otherwise
next time.    P( "UNITE" ) = 0.1 CDU + SPD + FDP
==================================================   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.4 Never been formed on the federal level, but not
unlikely. On the other hand SPD and CDU don't want
to be in a coalition anymore.   P( "UNITE" ) = 0.05 SPD + FDP + Green Party "Stoplight Coalition"
==================================================   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.4 FDP would be the sole right party in this coalition.
This coalition would also be a novelty on the federal level.   P( "UNITE" ) = 0.1 SPD + Left Party + Green Party
================================================== The political nightmare of the conservatives in Germany has
a chance of materializing for the first time on the federal
level in 2021.   P( "WIN>50%" ) = 0.3 Despite strong leaning to the left (as its name suggests),
the Left Party is politically not as isolated as its right wing counterpart, 
the AFD. So the formation of this pure left coalition is more likely than
the formation of the pure right CDU + FDP + AFD coalition.   P( "UNITE" ) = 0.25 Construct the Final Forecast
================================================== < Coalition  |  P( "WIN>50%" )  |  P( "UNITE" )  |  Result  |  Bucket  > CDU + FDP  |  0.2  |  0.95  |  0.19  |  CDU only CDU + SPD  |  0.3  |  0.25  |  0.075  |  CDU only SPD + Green Party  |  0.2  |  0.8  |  0.16  | Greens only CDU + AFD  |  0.2  |  0.1  |  0.02  |  CDU only CDU + Green Party  |  0.45  |  0.15  |  0.0675  |  CDU and Greens CDU + FDP + AFD  |  0.4  |  0.02  |  0.008  |  CDU only CDU + SPD + Green Party  |  0.65  |  0.05  |  0.0325  |  CDU and Greens CDU + FDP + Green Party  |  0.55  |  0.1  |  0.055  |  CDU and Greens CDU + SPD + FDP  |  0.4  |  0.05  |  0.02  |  CDU only SPD + FDP + Green Party  |  0.4  |  0.1  |  0.04  |  Greens only SPD + Left Party + Green Party  |  0.3  |  0.25  |  0.075  |  Greens only Checksum: 0.743 -> 0.257 left for "no government" option NOTE: Something has to happen so the options must add up to 1. Especially
the forecast is logically inconsistent if the sum of the possible coalitions
exceeds 1 (happened to me, so I had to adjust). Summary
================================================== CDU only:  0.313 ~ 31 %
Greens only:  0.275 ~ 28 %
CDU and Greens:  0.155 ~ 16 %
Neither CDU nor Greens:  0 %
--------------------------------------------------------
No government: 25 %

At first I thought this was quite difficult, but it seems like the acceptable combinations and range of pollings, makes this relatively straight forward. https://www.dw.com/en/cdu-csu-spd-afd-fdp-left-greens/a-38085900
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_German_federal_election It feels like the potential outcomes of relevance here are:
1. CDU/CSU and Greens plus any or none of FDP or SPD (or indeed AfD or Left)
2. CDU/CSU and SPD  (and indeed potentially others, excluding Greens)
3. CDU/CSP and FDP (and indeed potentially others, excluding Greens)
4. SPD, Greens plus possibly  Left (or indeed others)
5. No Government forming
6. Something else 2 - this feels difficult to me. Currently the CDU/CSU and SPD are polling at around 40%. It would need a relatively big shift to get that above 50% (and the seats do seem to end up close to proportional on seats), especially given that CDU/CSU seem to be on a downward trend. I also cannot see that grouping really working with any of the other 3 parties. Finally, even if these two got above 50% not sure, why they would exclude the Greens, especially if they are polling above the SPD (which again, momentum and recent polling would suggest they will, just seems tough politically unless the Greens had a terrible night, or SDP or CDU/CSU had a great one. So maybe something like 15% chance that the coalition works mathematically, and let's err on the side of generous and call it 75/25 that if it does work they would go for it. 3 - this seems very remote as it does not seem there are any acceptable coalition partners for these two - maybe 5% chance of these two having the required seats. If it does work they would probably go for it. 4 - Currently polling at a bit below 40%, but Greens seem to have momentum. Plus the Left are probably an extreme, but not impossible coalition partner. Let's call it c. 15% chance that Greens and SDP could form a coalition Government, but a high chance that they would do so if they could, and a non-zero chance they team up with the left, to put this possibility at 15%. Feels like the FDP plus these two has a high chance of working, but does not seem like a natural coalition at all, and almost definitionally, the CDU, Green and SPD would be an alternative. 5. Feels like this is more or less a negative. It feels very unlikely that  a combination of CSU/CDU, Greens and SDP would work (maybe as high as 85/90%, and this does feel like a very acceptable coalition, so perhaps an 95% chance that they manage to put it together if they can, plus 5% chance it is CSU/CDU and FDP. That would get you to c. 10% chance of no Government. That actually sounds high, but the difficulties with some of the other coalitions and issues with AfD does make me comfortable being a bit higher than history. 6. SPD and FDP almost impossible to work. AfD being a dominant force would need polls to be well out and even if they got 30% of the vote, suspect that just ends up as no Government. Putting this as a 1%, "anything can happen" but very unlikely Together this would get me to:
-Cdu only 16%
- Green party only 15%
- both 58%
- Neither 1%
- No Government 10% Not far from the consensus. Bit more probability on Greens without CDU which I am happy with given the CDU leadership uncertainty. May be underestimating the political likelihood of FDP, SPD and Greens - will think about that.

CDU and Grüne will be the most likely coalition but I see there is a chance that the CDU will gain back some support they have lost recently and therefore might be able to form a coalition with the reds and also there might be no government formed in time if there is a major scandal or if the majorities are in a way that do allow many options.

According to current polls [1] there is no option without either CDU or Greens as the two of them reach more than 50% of the seats. And these come after a massive drop of support for CDU/CSU over the latest round of mishandling of the corona crisis. So normally I would expect them to bounce back. However, they seem intent to sabotage themselves further (inability to decide on a leader and more importantly unable to do the selection process sufficiently quietly)... There are two components driving the uncertainty of the election outcome: 
1) there is still half a year left in which we will (barring complete incompetence or active sabotage) at least largely deal with Covid (vaccinations will be done, ICUs and clinics more broadly will be back to normal operations). This should drive back some support to SPD and CDU, potentially taking from Greens, Liberals and Lefts.
2) there is no clear leadership in the Greens. Especially none that has executive experience. If it looks like the Greens will be strongest party this might induce some hesitancy. On the other hand the question asks after the government and not the makeup of the Bundestag. In order for a new government to be seated (and the old government to be shown the door) the Bundestag has to elect a new chancellor [2]. This is a simple yes-no vote, where the Bundespräsident is selecting the candidate [3]. Interestingly enough I didn't find a specific writeup in whom the president can nominate. But typically this is the leader of the strongest party. 
In practice, this is slightly more convoluted as there is a phase where negotiations between the parties (technically the fractions, i.e. the representatives in the Bundestag of each party) happen. In these "Koalitionsverhandlungen" the plan for the government is written up and the ministries are assigned. This does not has constitutional standing and the Bundespräsident could decide to not care and just nominate someone.
If the nominee fails to get a majority, the Bundestag has 14 days to nominate someone themselves, if this someone gets 51% he/she will have to be named chancellor (by the president), if that also fails a plurality would be sufficient, but the president could choose to dissolve the Bundestag and trigger a new election [4]. In practice this timeout only starts after the president nominates someone which (by convention) only happens after there were successful Koalitionsverhandlungen. This is a long way of saying: There is very little in terms of formal requirements to form a new government (the nomination of ministers is a simple announcement by the chancellor and consecutive naming by the president), but there is a lot of things that typically happen before one is formed. In particular, after the last election this took a very long time [5]. There are a number of reasons why there shouldn't be a large delay this time around:
a) it was the FDP which was indecisive and it cost them dearly. They won't repeat this kind of delay, where a government is nearly formed and then called off in the last second
b) in 2017 it was clear the Merkel would stay on as chancellor, meaning that the government was still effective on the international level 
c) at the moment there is general discontent with the government (mostly the abyssal communication of the covid efforts) which raises the downside of a potential reelection. Still my guess of a new government being formed quickly (80%) is mostly guesswork. I assume that the new government has a majority in the Bundestag [6] and then either CDU or Greens will have to be in it (barring a collapse of both -> 0% neither). The CDU has more (executive) experience, is slightly stronger in the polls right now and has a realistic option of forming a government w/o Greens (CDU/SPD/FDP) leading me to favour w/ CDU w/o Greens over w/o CDU w/ Greens, but both is more likely than either of those options. The exact numbers are again mostly guess work. Things that would make me significantly reconsider this prediction:
- A rebound (>2%) or massive drop (<-4%) in polling values of the CDU/CSU (if combined with a bounce for the FDP: Drop w/o CDU w/ Green otherwise increase both)
- A massive increase (>5%) for the Greens (if combined with a bounce of the SPD: drop w/ CDU w/o Greens, otherwise increase both)
- A significant drop (<-3%) for the Greens (increase w/ CDU w/o Greens, increase both) [1] https://www.bundestagswahl-2021.de/umfragen/
[2] https://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/faqs/DE/themen/verfassung/regierungsbildung/regierungsbildung-liste.html
[3] http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/gg/art_63.html
[4] I don't think this ever happened
[5] https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bundestagswahl_2017#Regierungsbildung
[6] technically there could be a Minderheitsregierung, but unless it is formed by the Greens I do not see anyone able or willing to form it.

CDU are not as dominant as they have historically been.  Pandemic has cost them their reputation.   March election results were bad but not a disaster.  Greens hung on in Baden-Württemberg.   As the year goes on, CDU have a cahnce to redeem themselves with Vaccination programme and recover from scandals
Csu is the traditional pick and greens are the future

Honored that my question suggestion is live now at GJ Open, and I am now under pressure to make a forecast ;-).
First, the easy part:
Yes, it took forever last time for a coalition to form. This year we there is a pandemic; as opposed to the relatively uneventful winter of 2017/18, Germans would not accept coalition negotiations stretching into the next year.
Remains the tricky part of predicting who will build a coalition in 2021. A very helpful (German language) page is 
https://www.bundestagswahl-2021.de/koalitionen/ ; you can see that none of the actual coalitions of the past have a shot at a majority in the Bundestag, even CDU/CSU+SPD might, for the first time in history, not reach half of the seats together. 
CDU/CSU will be, despite their internal conflict, almost for sure be the strongest party and try to form a coalition. 
The Greens will be, almost for sure, number two.
If CDU/CSU+Greens reach a majority, it is likely they overcome their differences and form a coalition (like in Austria, where this coalition formed even before Corona).
If CDU/CSU+Greens don’t reach a majority, they will try again to form a “Jamaica” coalition together with the FDP; as the FDP, after leaving the Jamaica talks in 17/18, subsequently lost heavily in support, they will be inclined to join this time (plus the pressure taking responsibility due the health crisis).
All other options are pretty unlikely:
The “Kenia” variant with CDU/CSU+Greens+SPD will be pretty oversized (therefore unlikely, see Axelrod’s minimal connected winning coalition theorem:  https%3A%2F%2Flirias.kuleuven.be%2Fretrieve%2F280402&usg=AOvVaw0fZrpEqCKRUWhhRk47r9KR )
The “Germany” CDU/CSU+SPD+FDP would be novel, and very surprising outcome, as there are be even more differences to overcome.
All in all,
-	very unlikely no coalition this year
-	very unlikely neither CDU nor Greens in it
-	very likely both of them are part of it
